trans-unit.source: Packages, Metapackages and Frameworks
trans-unit.target: Packages, Metapackages and Frameworks

trans-unit.source: Packages, Metapackages and Frameworks
trans-unit.target: Packages, Metapackages and Frameworks

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Packages, Metapackages and Frameworks
trans-unit.target: Packages, Metapackages and Frameworks

trans-unit.source: .NET Core is a platform made of NuGet packages.
trans-unit.target: .NET Core is a platform made of NuGet packages.

trans-unit.source: Some product experiences benefit from fine-grained definition of packages while others from coarse-grained.
trans-unit.target: Some product experiences benefit from fine-grained definition of packages while others from coarse-grained.

trans-unit.source: To accommodate this duality, the product is distributed as a fine-grained set of packages and then described in courser chunks with a package type informally called a "metapackage".
trans-unit.target: To accommodate this duality, the product is distributed as a fine-grained set of packages and then described in courser chunks with a package type informally called a "metapackage".

trans-unit.source: Each of the .NET Core packages support being run on multiple .NET runtimes, represented as frameworks.
trans-unit.target: Each of the .NET Core packages support being run on multiple .NET runtimes, represented as frameworks.

trans-unit.source: Some of those frameworks are traditional frameworks, like `net46`, representing the .NET Framework.
trans-unit.target: Some of those frameworks are traditional frameworks, like `net46`, representing the .NET Framework.

trans-unit.source: Another set is new frameworks that can be thought of as "package-based frameworks", which establish a new model for defining frameworks.
trans-unit.target: Another set is new frameworks that can be thought of as "package-based frameworks", which establish a new model for defining frameworks.

trans-unit.source: These package-based frameworks are entirely formed and defined as packages, forming a strong relationship between packages and frameworks.
trans-unit.target: These package-based frameworks are entirely formed and defined as packages, forming a strong relationship between packages and frameworks.

trans-unit.source: Packages
trans-unit.target: Packages

trans-unit.source: .NET Core is split into a set of packages, which provide primitives, higher-level data types, app composition types and common utilities.
trans-unit.target: .NET Core is split into a set of packages, which provide primitives, higher-level data types, app composition types and common utilities.

trans-unit.source: Each of these packages represent a single assembly of the same name.
trans-unit.target: Each of these packages represent a single assembly of the same name.

trans-unit.source: For example, [System.Runtime](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Runtime) contains System.Runtime.dll.
trans-unit.target: For example, [System.Runtime](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Runtime) contains System.Runtime.dll.

trans-unit.source: There are advantages to defining packages in a fine-grained manner:
trans-unit.target: There are advantages to defining packages in a fine-grained manner:

trans-unit.source: Fine-grained packages can ship on their own schedule with relatively limited testing of other packages.
trans-unit.target: Fine-grained packages can ship on their own schedule with relatively limited testing of other packages.

trans-unit.source: Fine-grained packages can provide differing OS and CPU support.
trans-unit.target: Fine-grained packages can provide differing OS and CPU support.

trans-unit.source: Fine-grained packages can have dependencies specific to only one library.
trans-unit.target: Fine-grained packages can have dependencies specific to only one library.

trans-unit.source: Apps are smaller because unreferenced packages don't become part of the app distribution.
trans-unit.target: Apps are smaller because unreferenced packages don't become part of the app distribution.

trans-unit.source: Some of these benefits are only used in certain circumstances.
trans-unit.target: Some of these benefits are only used in certain circumstances.

trans-unit.source: For example, NET Core packages will typically ship on the same schedule with the same platform support.
trans-unit.target: For example, NET Core packages will typically ship on the same schedule with the same platform support.

trans-unit.source: In the case of servicing, fixes can be distributed and installed as small single package updates.
trans-unit.target: In the case of servicing, fixes can be distributed and installed as small single package updates.

trans-unit.source: Due to the narrow scope of change, the validation and time to make a fix available is limited to what is needed for a single library.
trans-unit.target: Due to the narrow scope of change, the validation and time to make a fix available is limited to what is needed for a single library.

trans-unit.source: The following is a list of the key NuGet packages for .NET Core:
trans-unit.target: The following is a list of the key NuGet packages for .NET Core:

trans-unit.source: [System.Runtime](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Runtime) - The most fundamental .NET Core package, including [Object](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Object), [String](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.String), [Array](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Array), [Action](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Action) and [IList<T>](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Collections.Generic.IList-1).
trans-unit.target: [System.Runtime](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Runtime) - The most fundamental .NET Core package, including [Object](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Object), [String](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.String), [Array](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Array), [Action](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Action) and [IList<T>](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Collections.Generic.IList-1).

trans-unit.source: [System.Collections](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Collections) - A set of (primarily) generic collections, including [List<T>](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Collections.Generic.List-1) and [Dictionary<K,V>](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary-2).
trans-unit.target: [System.Collections](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Collections) - A set of (primarily) generic collections, including [List<T>](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Collections.Generic.List-1) and [Dictionary<K,V>](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary-2).

trans-unit.source: [System.Net.Http](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Net.Http) - A set of types for HTTP network communication, including [HttpClient](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Net.Http.HttpClient) and [HttpResponseMessage](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage).
trans-unit.target: [System.Net.Http](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Net.Http) - A set of types for HTTP network communication, including [HttpClient](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Net.Http.HttpClient) and [HttpResponseMessage](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage).

trans-unit.source: [System.IO.FileSystem](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.IO.FileSystem) - A set of types for reading and writing to local or networked disk-based storage, including [File](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.IO.File) and [Directory](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.IO.Directory).
trans-unit.target: [System.IO.FileSystem](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.IO.FileSystem) - A set of types for reading and writing to local or networked disk-based storage, including [File](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.IO.File) and [Directory](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.IO.Directory).

trans-unit.source: [System.Linq](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Linq) - A set of types for querying objects, including Enumerable and [ILookup<TKey, TElement>](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Linq.ILookup-2);.
trans-unit.target: [System.Linq](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Linq) - A set of types for querying objects, including Enumerable and [ILookup<TKey, TElement>](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Linq.ILookup-2);.

trans-unit.source: [System.Reflection](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Reflection) - A set of types for loading, inspecting and activating types, including [Assembly](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Reflection.Assembly), [TypeInfo](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Reflection.TypeInfo) and [MethodInfo](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Reflection.MethodInfo).
trans-unit.target: [System.Reflection](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Reflection) - A set of types for loading, inspecting and activating types, including [Assembly](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Reflection.Assembly), [TypeInfo](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Reflection.TypeInfo) and [MethodInfo](http://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Reflection.MethodInfo).

trans-unit.source: Packages are referenced in project.json.
trans-unit.target: Packages are referenced in project.json.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, the [System.Runtime](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Runtime/) package is referenced.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, the [System.Runtime](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Runtime/) package is referenced.

trans-unit.source: In most cases, you will not reference the lower-level .NET Core packages directly since you'll end up with too many packages to manage.
trans-unit.target: In most cases, you will not reference the lower-level .NET Core packages directly since you'll end up with too many packages to manage.

trans-unit.source: Instead, you'll reference a metapackage.
trans-unit.target: Instead, you'll reference a metapackage.

trans-unit.source: Metapackages
trans-unit.target: Metapackages

trans-unit.source: Metapackages are a NuGet package convention for describing a set of packages that are meaningful together.
trans-unit.target: Metapackages are a NuGet package convention for describing a set of packages that are meaningful together.

trans-unit.source: They represent this set of packages by making them dependencies.
trans-unit.target: They represent this set of packages by making them dependencies.

trans-unit.source: They can optionally establish a framework for this set of packages by specifying a framework.
trans-unit.target: They can optionally establish a framework for this set of packages by specifying a framework.

trans-unit.source: By refg a metapackage, you are, in effect, adding a reference to each of its dependent packages as a single gesture.
trans-unit.target: By refg a metapackage, you are, in effect, adding a reference to each of its dependent packages as a single gesture.

trans-unit.source: That means that all of the libraries in those packages (refs or libs) are available for IntelliSense (or similar experience) and for publishing (libs only) your app.
trans-unit.target: That means that all of the libraries in those packages (refs or libs) are available for IntelliSense (or similar experience) and for publishing (libs only) your app.

trans-unit.source: Note: The 'lib' and 'ref' terms refer to folders in NuGet packages.
trans-unit.target: Note: The 'lib' and 'ref' terms refer to folders in NuGet packages.

trans-unit.source: 'ref' folders describe the public API of a package via assembly metadata.
trans-unit.target: 'ref' folders describe the public API of a package via assembly metadata.

trans-unit.source: 'lib' folders contain the implementation of that public API for a given framework.
trans-unit.target: 'lib' folders contain the implementation of that public API for a given framework.

trans-unit.source: There are advantages to using metapackages:
trans-unit.target: There are advantages to using metapackages:

trans-unit.source: Provides a convenient user experience to reference a large set of fine-grained packages.
trans-unit.target: Provides a convenient user experience to reference a large set of fine-grained packages.

trans-unit.source: Defines a set of packages (including specific versions) that are tested and work well together.
trans-unit.target: Defines a set of packages (including specific versions) that are tested and work well together.

trans-unit.source: The .NET Standard Library metapackage:
trans-unit.target: The .NET Standard Library metapackage:

trans-unit.source: [NETStandard.Library](https://www.nuget.org/packages/NETStandard.Library) - Describes the libraries that are part of the ".NET Standard Library".
trans-unit.target: [NETStandard.Library](https://www.nuget.org/packages/NETStandard.Library) - Describes the libraries that are part of the ".NET Standard Library".

trans-unit.source: Applies to all .NET implementations (for example, .NET Framework, .NET Core and Mono) that support the .NET Standard Library.
trans-unit.target: Applies to all .NET implementations (for example, .NET Framework, .NET Core and Mono) that support the .NET Standard Library.

trans-unit.source: Establishes the 'netstandard' framework.
trans-unit.target: Establishes the 'netstandard' framework.

trans-unit.source: These are the key .NET Core metapackages:
trans-unit.target: These are the key .NET Core metapackages:

trans-unit.source: [Microsoft.NETCore.App](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.NETCore.App) - Describes the libraries that are part of the .NET Core distribution.
trans-unit.target: [Microsoft.NETCore.App](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.NETCore.App) - Describes the libraries that are part of the .NET Core distribution.

trans-unit.source: Establishes the [`.NETCoreApp` framework](https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/blob/master/pkg/projects/Microsoft.NETCore.App/Microsoft.NETCore.App.pkgproj).
trans-unit.target: Establishes the [`.NETCoreApp` framework](https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/blob/master/pkg/projects/Microsoft.NETCore.App/Microsoft.NETCore.App.pkgproj).

trans-unit.source: Depends on the smaller `NETStandard.Library`.
trans-unit.target: Depends on the smaller `NETStandard.Library`.

trans-unit.source: [Microsoft.NETCore.Portable.Compatibility](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.NETCore.Portable.Compatibility) - A set of compatibility facades that enable mscorlib-based Portable Class Libraries (PCLs) to run on .NET Core.
trans-unit.target: [Microsoft.NETCore.Portable.Compatibility](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.NETCore.Portable.Compatibility) - A set of compatibility facades that enable mscorlib-based Portable Class Libraries (PCLs) to run on .NET Core.

trans-unit.source: Metapackages are referenced just like any other NuGet package in project.json.
trans-unit.target: Metapackages are referenced just like any other NuGet package in project.json.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, the `NETStandard.Library` meta package is referenced, which is used for creating libraries that are portable across .NET runtimes.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, the `NETStandard.Library` meta package is referenced, which is used for creating libraries that are portable across .NET runtimes.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, the `Microsoft.NETCore.App` metapackage is referenced, which is used for creating apps and libraries that are intended to run on and take full advantage of .NET Core.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, the `Microsoft.NETCore.App` metapackage is referenced, which is used for creating apps and libraries that are intended to run on and take full advantage of .NET Core.

trans-unit.source: It provides access to a larger set of libraries than are provided by `NETStandard.Library`.
trans-unit.target: It provides access to a larger set of libraries than are provided by `NETStandard.Library`.

trans-unit.source: Frameworks
trans-unit.target: Frameworks

trans-unit.source: .NET Core packages each support a set of frameworks, declared with framework folders (within the lib and ref folders mentioned earlier).
trans-unit.target: .NET Core packages each support a set of frameworks, declared with framework folders (within the lib and ref folders mentioned earlier).

trans-unit.source: Frameworks describe an available API set (and potentially other characteristics) that you can rely on when you target a given framework.
trans-unit.target: Frameworks describe an available API set (and potentially other characteristics) that you can rely on when you target a given framework.

trans-unit.source: They are versioned as new APIs are added.
trans-unit.target: They are versioned as new APIs are added.

trans-unit.source: For example, [System.IO.FileSystem](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.IO.FileSystem) supports the following frameworks:
trans-unit.target: For example, [System.IO.FileSystem](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.IO.FileSystem) supports the following frameworks:

trans-unit.source: .NETFramework,Version=4.6
trans-unit.target: .NETFramework,Version=4.6

trans-unit.source: .NETStandard,Version=1.3
trans-unit.target: .NETStandard,Version=1.3

trans-unit.source: 6 Xamarin platforms (for example, xamarinios10)
trans-unit.target: 6 Xamarin platforms (for example, xamarinios10)

trans-unit.source: It is useful to contrast the first two of these frameworks, since they are examples of the two different ways that frameworks are defined.
trans-unit.target: It is useful to contrast the first two of these frameworks, since they are examples of the two different ways that frameworks are defined.

trans-unit.source: The `.NETFramework,Version=4.6` framework represents the available APIs in the .NET Framework 4.6.
trans-unit.target: The `.NETFramework,Version=4.6` framework represents the available APIs in the .NET Framework 4.6.

trans-unit.source: You can produce libraries compiled with the .NET Framework 4.6 reference assemblies and then distribute those libraries in NuGet packages in a net46 lib folder.
trans-unit.target: You can produce libraries compiled with the .NET Framework 4.6 reference assemblies and then distribute those libraries in NuGet packages in a net46 lib folder.

trans-unit.source: It will be used for apps that target the .NET Framework 4.6 or that are compatible with it.
trans-unit.target: It will be used for apps that target the .NET Framework 4.6 or that are compatible with it.

trans-unit.source: This is how all frameworks have traditionally worked.
trans-unit.target: This is how all frameworks have traditionally worked.

trans-unit.source: The `.NETStandard,Version=1.3` framework is a package-based framework.
trans-unit.target: The `.NETStandard,Version=1.3` framework is a package-based framework.

trans-unit.source: It relies on packages that target the framework to define and expose APIs in terms of the framework.
trans-unit.target: It relies on packages that target the framework to define and expose APIs in terms of the framework.

trans-unit.source: Package-based Frameworks
trans-unit.target: Package-based Frameworks

trans-unit.source: There is a two-way relationship between frameworks and packages.
trans-unit.target: There is a two-way relationship between frameworks and packages.

trans-unit.source: The first part is defining the APIs available for a given framework, for example `netstandard1.3`.
trans-unit.target: The first part is defining the APIs available for a given framework, for example `netstandard1.3`.

trans-unit.source: Packages that target `netstandard1.3` (or compatible frameworks, like `netstandard1.0`) define the APIs available for `netstandard1.3`.
trans-unit.target: Packages that target `netstandard1.3` (or compatible frameworks, like `netstandard1.0`) define the APIs available for `netstandard1.3`.

trans-unit.source: That may sound like a circular definition, but it isn't.
trans-unit.target: That may sound like a circular definition, but it isn't.

trans-unit.source: By virtue of being "package-based", the API definition for the framework comes from packages.
trans-unit.target: By virtue of being "package-based", the API definition for the framework comes from packages.

trans-unit.source: The framework itself doesn't define any APIs.
trans-unit.target: The framework itself doesn't define any APIs.

trans-unit.source: The second part of the relationship is asset selection.
trans-unit.target: The second part of the relationship is asset selection.

trans-unit.source: Packages can contain assets for multiple frameworks.
trans-unit.target: Packages can contain assets for multiple frameworks.

trans-unit.source: Given a reference to a set of packages and/or metapackages, the framework is needed to determine which asset should be selected, for example `net46` or `netstandard1.3`.
trans-unit.target: Given a reference to a set of packages and/or metapackages, the framework is needed to determine which asset should be selected, for example `net46` or `netstandard1.3`.

trans-unit.source: It is important to select the correct asset.
trans-unit.target: It is important to select the correct asset.

trans-unit.source: For example, a `net46` asset is not likely to be compatible with .NET Framework 4.0 or .NET Core 1.0.
trans-unit.target: For example, a `net46` asset is not likely to be compatible with .NET Framework 4.0 or .NET Core 1.0.

trans-unit.source: Package-based Framework Composition
trans-unit.target: Package-based Framework Composition

trans-unit.source: You can see this relationship in the image above.
trans-unit.target: You can see this relationship in the image above.

trans-unit.source: The *API* targets and defines the *framework*.
trans-unit.target: The *API* targets and defines the *framework*.

trans-unit.source: The *framework* is used for *asset selection*.
trans-unit.target: The *framework* is used for *asset selection*.

trans-unit.source: The *asset* gives you the API.
trans-unit.target: The *asset* gives you the API.

trans-unit.source: It is an interesting question of where a package-based framework's definition ends and where consumption of that definition starts.
trans-unit.target: It is an interesting question of where a package-based framework's definition ends and where consumption of that definition starts.

trans-unit.source: One can consider your view of the framework as a function of a given project.json file.
trans-unit.target: One can consider your view of the framework as a function of a given project.json file.

trans-unit.source: Your dependencies create your view of the framework, independent of the publisher(s) of those dependencies.
trans-unit.target: Your dependencies create your view of the framework, independent of the publisher(s) of those dependencies.

trans-unit.source: The two primary package-based frameworks used with .NET Core are:
trans-unit.target: The two primary package-based frameworks used with .NET Core are:

trans-unit.source: .NET Standard
trans-unit.target: .NET Standard

trans-unit.source: The .NET Standard (TFM: `netstandard`) framework represents the APIs defined by and built on top of the [.NET Standard Library](../standard/library.md).
trans-unit.target: The .NET Standard (TFM: `netstandard`) framework represents the APIs defined by and built on top of the [.NET Standard Library](../standard/library.md).

trans-unit.source: Libraries that are intended to run on multiple runtimes should target this framework.
trans-unit.target: Libraries that are intended to run on multiple runtimes should target this framework.

trans-unit.source: They will be supported on any .NET Standard compliant runtime, such as .NET Core, .NET Framework and Mono/Xamarin.
trans-unit.target: They will be supported on any .NET Standard compliant runtime, such as .NET Core, .NET Framework and Mono/Xamarin.

trans-unit.source: Each of these runtimes supports a set of .NET Standard versions, depending on which APIs they implement.
trans-unit.target: Each of these runtimes supports a set of .NET Standard versions, depending on which APIs they implement.

trans-unit.source: The `NETStandard.Library` metapackage targets the `netstandard` framework.
trans-unit.target: The `NETStandard.Library` metapackage targets the `netstandard` framework.

trans-unit.source: The most common way to target `netstandard` is by referencing this metapackage.
trans-unit.target: The most common way to target `netstandard` is by referencing this metapackage.

trans-unit.source: It describes and provides access to the ~40 .NET libraries and associated APIs that define the .NET Standard Library.
trans-unit.target: It describes and provides access to the ~40 .NET libraries and associated APIs that define the .NET Standard Library.

trans-unit.source: You can reference additional packages that target `netstandard` to get access to additional APIs.
trans-unit.target: You can reference additional packages that target `netstandard` to get access to additional APIs.

trans-unit.source: A given [NETStandard.Library version](versions/index.md) matches the highest `netstandard` version it exposed (via its closure).
trans-unit.target: A given [NETStandard.Library version](versions/index.md) matches the highest `netstandard` version it exposed (via its closure).

trans-unit.source: The framework reference in project.json is used to select the correct assets from the underlying packages.
trans-unit.target: The framework reference in project.json is used to select the correct assets from the underlying packages.

trans-unit.source: In this case, `netstandard1.5` assets are required, as opposed to `netstandard1.4` or `net46`, for example.
trans-unit.target: In this case, `netstandard1.5` assets are required, as opposed to `netstandard1.4` or `net46`, for example.

trans-unit.source: The framework and metapackage references in project.json do not need to match.
trans-unit.target: The framework and metapackage references in project.json do not need to match.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following project.json is valid.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following project.json is valid.

trans-unit.source: It may seem strange to target `netstandard1.3` but use the 1.5.0 version of `NETStandard.Library`.
trans-unit.target: It may seem strange to target `netstandard1.3` but use the 1.5.0 version of `NETStandard.Library`.

trans-unit.source: It is a valid use-case, since the metapackage maintains support for older `netstandard` versions.
trans-unit.target: It is a valid use-case, since the metapackage maintains support for older `netstandard` versions.

trans-unit.source: It could be the case you've standardized on the 1.5.0 version of the metapackage and use it for all your libraries, which target a variety of `netstandard` versions.
trans-unit.target: It could be the case you've standardized on the 1.5.0 version of the metapackage and use it for all your libraries, which target a variety of `netstandard` versions.

trans-unit.source: With this approach, you only need to restore `NETStandard.Library` 1.5.0 and not earlier versions.
trans-unit.target: With this approach, you only need to restore `NETStandard.Library` 1.5.0 and not earlier versions.

trans-unit.source: The reverse would not be valid: targeting `netstandard1.5` with the 1.3.0 version of `NETStandard.Library`.
trans-unit.target: The reverse would not be valid: targeting `netstandard1.5` with the 1.3.0 version of `NETStandard.Library`.

trans-unit.source: You cannot target a higher framework with a lower metapackage, since the lower version metapackage will not expose any assets for that higher framework.
trans-unit.target: You cannot target a higher framework with a lower metapackage, since the lower version metapackage will not expose any assets for that higher framework.

trans-unit.source: The [versioning scheme] for metapackages asserts that metapackages match the highest version of the framework they describe.
trans-unit.target: The [versioning scheme] for metapackages asserts that metapackages match the highest version of the framework they describe.

trans-unit.source: By virtue of the versioning scheme, the first version of `NETStandard.Library` is v1.5.0 given that it contains `netstandard1.5` assets.
trans-unit.target: By virtue of the versioning scheme, the first version of `NETStandard.Library` is v1.5.0 given that it contains `netstandard1.5` assets.

trans-unit.source: v1.3.0 is used in the example above, for symmetry with the example above, but does not actually exist.
trans-unit.target: v1.3.0 is used in the example above, for symmetry with the example above, but does not actually exist.

trans-unit.source: .NET Core Application
trans-unit.target: .NET Core Application

trans-unit.source: The .NET Core Application (TFM: `netcoreapp`) framework represents the packages and associated APIs that come with the .NET Core distribution and the console application model that it provides.
trans-unit.target: The .NET Core Application (TFM: `netcoreapp`) framework represents the packages and associated APIs that come with the .NET Core distribution and the console application model that it provides.

trans-unit.source: .NET Core apps must use this framework, due to targeting the console application model, as should libraries that intended to run only on .NET Core.
trans-unit.target: .NET Core apps must use this framework, due to targeting the console application model, as should libraries that intended to run only on .NET Core.

trans-unit.source: Using this framework restricts apps and libraries to running only on .NET Core.
trans-unit.target: Using this framework restricts apps and libraries to running only on .NET Core.

trans-unit.source: The `Microsoft.NETCore.App` metapackage targets the `netcoreapp` framework.
trans-unit.target: The `Microsoft.NETCore.App` metapackage targets the `netcoreapp` framework.

trans-unit.source: It provides access to ~60 libraries, ~40 provided by the `NETStandard.Library` package and ~20 more in addition.
trans-unit.target: It provides access to ~60 libraries, ~40 provided by the `NETStandard.Library` package and ~20 more in addition.

trans-unit.source: You can reference additional libraries that target `netcoreapp` or compatible frameworks, such as `netstandard`, to get access to additional APIs.
trans-unit.target: You can reference additional libraries that target `netcoreapp` or compatible frameworks, such as `netstandard`, to get access to additional APIs.

trans-unit.source: Most of the additional libraries provided by `Microsoft.NETCore.App` also target `netstandard` given that their dependencies are satisfied by other `netstandard` libraries.
trans-unit.target: Most of the additional libraries provided by `Microsoft.NETCore.App` also target `netstandard` given that their dependencies are satisfied by other `netstandard` libraries.

trans-unit.source: That means that `netstandard` libraries can also reference those packages as dependencies.
trans-unit.target: That means that `netstandard` libraries can also reference those packages as dependencies.
